Changing base in logarithms

It is sometimes required to express the logarithm with respect to one base in terms of a logarithm with respect to another base.

Now \(b=a^n\) implies \(\log_ab=n\) where we have used logs to base \(a\). If for some reason we want to use another base, \(p\) say, then we do as follows.

We take logs to base \(p\) of both sides of \(b=a^n\), which gives \(\log_p(b)= \log_p(a^n)=n\log_pa\) (using one of the logarithm laws), so \(n=\dfrac{\log_p(b)}{\log_p(a)}\). But we also have \(\log_ab=n\).

Therefore, we conclude \(\log_ab=\dfrac{\log_p(b)}{\log_p(a)}.\)

This is the rule to be used when converting logarithms from one base to another.

Key Point

\[\log_ab=\dfrac{\log_p(b)}{\log_p(a)}.\]

For base 10 logs: \[\log_ab=\dfrac{\log (b)}{\log (a)}.\]

For natural logs: \[\log_ab=\dfrac{\ln (b)}{\ln (a)}.\]

Example 

For example, \(\log_37\) cannot be determined directly on your calculator since logs to base 3 are not available but it can be found using the above formulas (changing to base \(10\) or base \(e\)). \[\log_37=\dfrac{\log 7}{\log 3}=\dfrac{0.8450980}{0.4771212}=1.7712437\] (Check, on your calculator, that \(3^{1.7712437}=7\)).

Alternatively, \[\log_37=\dfrac{\ln 7}{\ln 3}=\dfrac{1.9459101}{1.0986123}=1.7712437\]
